text:
--zoology, you know, basketball,
and then you end up in the CIA. Did you take the wrong turn in
one of the recruiting booths,

or-- what happened? Did you always have an
interest in national security? Well, I always think
we are who we begin as,

and I'm the third child
of a Naval officer, right? So if you're the third child
of Bob and Shar Monroe,

you are taught two
things your whole life. One, you're supposed
to do your best, and you're supposed to do
something for the cause.

And so that's kind of who I was. I went to Duke to become
a world-famous aquanaut.

In my age group, on Sunday
nights, you watch two shows-- Mutual of Omaha Wild Kingdom
and The Undersea World

of Jacques Cousteau. And I had a great
teacher, and I just decided that's who
I was going to be. Unfortunately, there
weren't a lot of schools

that I wanted to go to that
had a marine biology program, but Duke had a marine science
consortium on the east coast.

I thought, well, that's perfect. If I don't want to be a marine
biologist, I can go to Duke and I can get that
there, and fortunately, I

played basketball and so I
never had my Spring times free. I went through school, I had
some great professors who--

I don't know, taught
me to be curious.

The great thing
about a zo degree is it's the mystery
of life stuff. And it will become
important in my career.

I couldn't decide if I wanted
to get my PhD in biomechanics

or go to law school,
because I love arguing, and so I decided to
find a job, and CIA

was recruiting on campus
and I went and interviewed, and I guess they saw
something in me they liked. I was hired to do analysis
of Soviet biological warfare,

so that makes sense, right? Critters. Unfortunately, when I show up
a bright, shiny 21-year-old,

my security clearance
all ready to go, they told me that
the job had been downsized during the recession
and I had 30 days to find work.

The only job I
could find was doing analysis of technical data from
the National Security Agency

on Soviet Naval missiles. And I said, well, I can do that. And they're like, wait, you
have a degree in zoology.

And I said that mechanical
engineering was really just applied zoology. [LAUGHTER]

OK, you laugh. Where do you find
frictionless joints? In a baby's knee.

Really. So they decided I was either
scary or really competent, and they hired me. And then I just had a place that
was kind of like, for me, peas

and carrots. It was big, so if you had big
ideas, you could do big things.

You were expected to
perform, and performance was more important than
pedigree, so pretty quickly,

they forgot that I had
this degree in zoology because I kept doing things. And I moved through doing
analysis of Soviet missiles

to analysis of Soviet spacecraft
to building US spacecrafts to building in-place
sensors to going into it

and just kind of moving along. And so there are lots of
lessons there for you. The biggest one is
you're going to do

lots of things in your life. You don't have to do it
all in the first year. And the second thing
is you're not stuck with the knowledge you have.

So one of the things I learned
a month ago, with you, on stage, actually, was that
getting into CIA

is even harder than getting
into Harvard or Stanford. It is. Which is just an
amazing statistic

of the people who apply. And that kind of, I think,
set maybe the milieu that you were in, right?

You were swimming in the sea of
other very smart and aggressive and creative people, just
like Stanford students.

Right. But you mentioned something else
that I thought was interesting, and you normally don't
hear it, but it's the key

to intelligence is curiosity. Tell me more about that. And because you
were an analyst, it

was obviously key to
things you were looking at and things you were
thinking about. How did that work
in your business?

So I don't know whether
this is a story I've made up or it's true, but actually--

It'll be true after you say it. So what's fun about
biology is it's

an inductive science, right? Whatever you see,
whatever organism that is, you presume
that it's doing

what it's doing perfectly. That's evolution. And your job is not
to judge the goodness,

but rather to understand
what it's doing. And that's actually,
fundamentally, what intelligence is about.

And that's what differs
from law enforcement, which tends to be more deductive. This is inductive. So number one, I was really
comfortable with this,

what am I looking at, what
am I seeing sort of thing. So that suited me
intellectually,

and so that kind of opens
up some really interesting possibilities when
you ask that question.

The second thing is when I
got into building systems, the CIA is really
unique in that it

doesn't do 800,000 of anything. You ever see the
movie A Few Good Men?

When Colonel Jessup is
on the stand, and says, you want us on that wall,
you need us on the wall.

The role of the CIA is to
do what no one else can, but you only have to do it once. So you can be crazy
big and crazy creative

because it must be solved and
it can't be solved in any way.

So that just, again, suited me. I'm an outcome gal. What do we need to do? I'm not wedded to any
particular path to that,

maybe because I wasn't-- I acquired expertise,
but you would never have considered me an expert.

And because of that,
I was not wedded to any solution that was based
on how I thought it should be.

So differently, I
was never righteous. I just wanted to be right. And so that opened up some-- That's a great line.

Sue, can you share
a little bit more about how your role evolved
at the CIA over the years?

Yeah, so you're going to think-- I described it as
a straight line.

It was not. My first job was
too easy, and so I

forgot that there was
a discipline to it. And one day, I was
alone and I made a call

based on technical data that
made a lot of sense to me, and I wrote an
article that somehow got into the president's book.

It turned out that I
was right technically, but I didn't understand
that what I had just done is the Soviets had tested a
missile that violated the START

treaty. Whoops. Whoops. Right? So think about that. I was right
technically, and this

is kind of a recurring
theme with Sue in terms of what I didn't understand. So that wasn't my best
day, but I recovered.

I got another job
in a really cool-- doing space policy at the
time that space policy

was so much fun. This is the ABM
treaty, and Star Wars,

and I was whizzing
along, and I had a boss that decided that I would--

he didn't like
women, particularly women who didn't have
degrees in engineering. And I was out on the west
coast, doing part of my job,

and when I came back, I
didn't have that job anymore. I was sent back to the
most grunty job in all

of the Office of Scientific
Weapons Research, which turned out to be the transportation
to the first part of my career,

because instead of being
someone who could talk good, I had to learn a craft.

And I will tell you,
you all are all so smart and people will hire
you to do things.

Make sure you actually learn
how to accomplish something. Don't be sucked into
a job where someone

wants you to be on their
staff or something like that because learning how to do
anything-- so I went backwards

in an unceremonious way. I did technical analysis
of Soviet communications

satellites, which are
really boring and dumb. Why didn't you quit?

Because I had a great boss who
said, Sue, you might be right. You may not have a future
here, but you don't ever

want to let someone think
that your performance is dependent on them.

So why don't you go ahead
and be good at your job, and then if you want to go,
then you can go to something?

And it actually
worked out that way. I'm 24 years old
when I'm deciding that they don't like me. I mean, in a way that only
a 24-year-old can think.

Like, they won't
recognize my brilliance. But I--
Story of my life. But I did, and I'll get there.

So I moved on, and I because
of the things I'd done in doing analysis of Soviet spacecraft,
it turned out that the US was

building a first-of-a-kind
spacecraft, super secret, only one ever built, a mission
I can't tell you about.

But it needed that
expertise, and so they hired this 25-year-old
former zoologist

to do subsystem design
for a spacecraft. I know, right?

How cool is that? And so I did that,
and then I had a boss that came to me and-- Wait a minute, did you just tell
us the CIA makes spacecraft?

Is that what you just told us? They do. They did then. Now there's-- A lot of
services used to do it,

now the National Reconnaissance
has consolidated all those things.

Oh, my gosh, you guys. Let me digress for
just one second.

The role of National Security
in the advance of technology in the United States
cannot be underestimated.

You want to know why
we're good at mammograms? It's because of
the imagery science that was developed as part of
our first photoreconnaissance

systems. There is so much
societal gain that has come from this pull
from national security.

This is a really fraught time
of strategic uncertainty, where we're going to be
developing a lot of new--

I will tell you that
it will be a great time to be a national security,
to be part of the pull,

not just part of the
development of the capabilities that will come. So it's all part of
the same, but this

is a really interesting time. So, no, we do build them. They let youngsters
do it, and that's

because they're so confident
in the craft surrounding them. And then I had a boss come to
me-- and this is a sign of--

you want to hear my
best failure story? Yeah, this is going to make
you feel better about anything you do in the future.

I'm giving you a future
pass based on my story. So I'm 26 years old, my
boss comes to me and said,

Sue, we need you to develop, in
six months, a brand new concept

for how we're going
to get data back from a clandestinely in-place
source, for the first time

ever, in real time. So we need to get data
from a really scary place that you don't want US people
to be known to be there,

and your solution
is going to make us have to go back fewer times. We have $3 billion
set aside for it.

We'd like your answer to come
back in under $3 billion.
Six months, here's $50 million. Go figure it out. Like, think about that, right?

That's just like this
undifferentiated task, and I will tell you, you
can't go to your boss and say, how do you want
me to figure it out?

Well, you can ask once. They'll kind of hem and haw. Do not ask a second time because
then they'll constrain you,

and they don't know. So I went off and I got
the air force involved, because if you're going to do
a low-power signal from Earth,

you've got to have a
lot of gain in space. And so talking to these guys
like, what kind of reflector

can you put on a spacecraft
that you haven't launched yet? And they're like, oh, if
you'll give me $1 million for a wiring harness, so
I'm making these deals.

Did I say I'm 26 years old
with a degree in zoology? And then I did the
Three Bear approach

to building the ground system. I went to a big company,
a medium-sized company, and a small company and
I said, work with me.

And darned if they didn't. And after four months,
we had a solution that was technically shocking,
only $650 million, ready to go.

And did it go? No. [LAUGHTER] So here's what
happened on one day.

The small company was the
one that had the best design. The problem is the
small company had only had a contract for $1 million
and had never been in debt,

and so because I'm a very
straight-shooting 26-year-old with my contractor, I
said, hey, love your design

but you're too small. We'll partner you with one of
the big guys in order to do it. I thought that was only
fair to tell them that.

One day, I come into work,
the head of the National Reconnaissance Office-- to me, that's tantamount to god.

Like, I had a boss
who was god-like, but this guy was
even more than that. I pick up the phone and
he says, Suzy-- and this

is that bad day, because
do I look like a Suzy? [LAUGHTER] He says, Suzy, I don't know
who the hell you think you are

or that stupid
agency you work for, but I want you to know that
it's going to be my life's work to make sure your project
never sees the light of day.

Those air force people
that have worked with you, they've already been
removed from their position and they will never get
promoted to another rank.

I don't care about
your solution. You didn't talk to any
of the stakeholders, you haven't talked
to congress, you

don't know the other
things we had planned. Over. I will not allow
this to ever succeed.

That was not the
worst call I had. The next call was
the worst call. I thought it was
going to be great.

It was the president
of the small company. He said, Sue, great news. I sold my company last
night to Westinghouse.

We can now take on the contract
that you're going to give us. Oh, no. Oh, no.

A man sold his life's work
because a 26-year-old was not

smart enough to
either understand that it's not the brilliance
of the technical solution,

it's all the things around
it that make it work. And I just wasn't experienced
to understand the limitations

of the relationship
between the government and the contractor
for good reason. So we'll do audience
participation.

What do you do
next, if you're me? Crying? Absolutely not.

That's later at
night, in my own home. What do I do next? This is really important. This is going to be the best
piece of advice I give you.

Yes, ma'am? Talk to your
contracting officer? Nope, close. You're on your way, but no.

Someone else leap
into the fray and then I'll give you the answer? What do you do next? Yes? You explain what just happened. Yes, you must go to your
boss and present yourself

for flogging. Like, there's nothing good
that happens if you don't.

So I go to my boss. Sorry this is so long winded. It's great. So I go to my boss and I
say, here's what happens.

And do you know
what the man said? And it changed my life. He said, oh, I've seen worse.

[LAUGHTER] It didn't mean it wasn't bad. It meant that he was
good enough his job

that he could allow me
to be expansive and still

recover from anything
that had happened. And he kicked me
back into the fray,

so I still had to learn all
the lessons, and trust me, I feel it to this day.

Sue-- I decided I wanted to be the
guy that could always say, I've seen worse.

So there are some
important lessons embedded in that
about stakeholders and understanding more
than just your core piece

of the shiny object. Can you expand on
that for a second? Because I think that's
pretty core to building

a successful organization,
is understanding all the stakeholders. So let's bounce one
higher than stakeholders.

Understand all the risks
associated with the program, and each stakeholder holds
a different kind of risk.

So I was really on
the engineering side, and risk to an engineer is
that your thing won't work.

Right? And I understood that. I delivered something
that worked. But risk, organizationally,
is that budget for this

will supplant--
that someone will be interested in this
more than the thing that the organization
have planned to do.

And I have inadvertently
created competition within the organization for
a competing mission priority.

That's another kind of risk. Congressional risk,
they don't like things that happen in the
middle of a budget cycle

that they weren't involved in. And congress, sometimes,
for retribution,

will not smack the
one that did the deed, but other priorities
that want to come along.

So, I mean, there are
just a number of these that, in that case,
those were the ones.

The way I would
tell to you is you have to think about
the ecosystem involved

in every project, or
your mantra should be, oh, you wanted it to work.

And we do this a lot. We'll talk about the
whole defense ecosystem

now throwing a capability
over the transom to somebody

else to say, you fit
it into your system. How likely is that
going to be successful?

Not-- Can you be
proud of the thing you threw over the transom. Absolutely. Does that count?

Absolutely not. There is no pride in,
but it was really good. They just didn't use it.

That's a great line. Right? So this idea of thinking end
to end about how it can work,

not just what it can do, is
a really important thing. You want to get your
boss to buy your idea?

Man, take it a lot
further, an idea. You know where great ideas
end up on your boss's desk?

Right there on the
set of things that I'm too busy to take care of.

You want them to do
something with them? Show them how they can have
it, not just what it is.

And so that's what
I didn't understand. It's like a really kind
of immutable principle that if you learn
it early, you're

going to be shocked at
how many of the things that you proffer will
actually be accepted.

That's great advice. So at what point
were you Manager Sue. That is, what point were
you Leader Sue versus--

Remember when I got
bounced out of the office because I wasn't
an engineer and I thought my career was over so I
went over to build spacecraft?

Neatly enough, when I went away
and did that, they called me up and say, hey, Sue,
we have this branch that needs managing back
in the same division.

And so I came back as a
first line supervisor at 27. Wow.
I was at GS-13. Wow. A leader of GS-15.
That's interesting. It was a great day.

And I sucked at it because-- no, no, no, because I
didn't yet understand

what leadership really is. It's how to be
accountable without having to do all the work yourself.

Right? Because it wasn't the standard
of how I would do each task.

It was the direction
I was going to set and the standard for the quality
of work, not the actual work

itself. And I sent a thank you note
to everyone in my branch that they were still
there after six months.

So I became Manager Sue, and
it turned out I was OK at that. It was the-- I got to do so
many great projects because it

was space missions division
right in the heyday of the space race. Sally Ride and I were
working on things together.

I briefed President Reagan. And then my boss
comes to me and says, hey, Sue, I'd like you
to go from this job

to be the deputy director of the
Information Systems Division. And I said, oh, no.

That sounds awful. Oh, come on, Steve. In 1989, IT and the
government was wiring closets.

It was just not sexy. And I thought I was
one of the cool kids

and I thought that was where
they put women and support officers. So I said no.

And he said, no, I really
want you to and I said no. And he came back and he
said, I really want you to, and I said yes. You know, if there's
someone you respect asked

you to do something, do it. And if the first failure of the
guy who wanted to kick me out

because I was a woman gave
me the first few years of my career, that
move to IT gave me

the middle part of my career. And that became how I
got into analytic tools

and what gave me the readiness
to receive the task on how we get to Silicon Valley
that became In-Q-Tel,

gave me the legs into cyber,
all because I was offered a job that I didn't want to do.

So I become Manager
Sue kind of throughout, and that's who I am
the rest of my days.

So-- Go ahead. No, definitely want to
revisit the In-Q-Tel story, but how did you then go from
CIA, NGA, DNI, you know,

that whole career arc? OK, so-- We should make this
the three-hour talk.
I'm really sorry. I'm trying to-- No, I don't know about you guys. --be short. I'm trying to be. I want stay all night.

If you walk out, I
will try and pretend that it wasn't in
a huff and that I won't have my feelings hurt.

So I'm trundling along. We'll get back to In-Q-Tel. I did In-Q-Tel-- oh, I
also got married in college

to the cutest guy ever,
who we just celebrated our 43rd wedding anniversary.

We have two kids. I cheated time,
all my years, of, How do you do really hard jobs
and have a family that you're

really committed to? And so I have a good engine, and
so I work lots of extra hours.

After I delivered
In-Q-Tel, the jig was up and I realized that I couldn't,
for me, both be great at work

and be great at home. Many people can figure
out how to do both. I could not, so I gave two
weeks notice and I resigned.

So from 1999 till 2007,
I'm Jane Casey's mom.

I did a little bit of
contracting after 9/11 because everyone came back after

And then I successfully
deployed my children into college and I looked
around and I said--

Did you realize you
were all deployed? Oh, come on. Your parents say it. It's all right.

You can-- Was it easy to jump back in? Yeah. Yeah, so I saw the head
of personnel at the CIA

in Wegmans, and I said,
hey, you guys hiring? And so I came back.

And I got into-- I had the greatest second
act ever for a career.

So the first was analysis,
then engineering, then information systems.

The second half was I became the
director of Special Activities at the CIA. Do you know what that?

Is that the best title ever? Yeah, just imagine what it
is and it's, like, way better

than that. It's super good. It's building covert action
tools for operations.

It was just the best job
ever, but that's another way of learning about risk. Then I became the
deputy director

of information operations. I'll tell you another way
that my jobs came to me. My boss called and
said, hey, Sue--

so I'm an office
director-- she said, hey, Sue, I'm
thinking I want you to become the deputy director
of Information Operations.

So I'm the chief, I'd like
you to become the deputy.
And I said-- She said, what do you think? And I said, I don't know. Do you want me to do it? And she said, I think I do.

And I said, OK. And she said, are we
going to talk about it? And I said no. Back to this, if
people you respect

tell you to do something, do it. So that got me into cyber
and information operations

in what I will say is
the pre-crazy heyday

of when it was
nation states acting in the wild west
beneath anyone's notice.

So was this before DDI,
or did this become-- So before, then I become
the director of support

because I'm the person
that you hire at the CIA if you want something done. Dave Petraeus made me
his director of support,

so that's security, finance,
logistics, medical, IT,

all those things. Great job, best job ever. The people who make the quiet
that lets mission happen

are really remarkable. Don't judge people
who do support. People who do
support are amazing. And then John Brennan
comes to me and said,

could you figure out
cyber for the agency? I said, what do you mean? He said, I don't know. I said, never mind.

I'll figure it out. And 90 days later, I delivered
a pretty transformative report about how the CIA could be
successful in the digital era,

which included the formation
of the Directorate of Digital Innovation. But because he really liked
it but the agency didn't

particularly, because I
moved a lot of cheese, I had to be voted off
the island because if you want to have the transformation
happen, sometimes

you have to take away the
personality from the person. So I was upset.

It was really awful. I loved the CIA. And I was offered the job
of deputy director at NGA.

If you're a CIA
officer, you're like, why would I want to do that? Another thing I
didn't want to do

or that was the product
of a failure, whichever the way you want to see it,
best thing that happened ever.

NGA taught me about
combat support. It taught me about
succeeding in the open. It taught me about
modern transformation.

What the director
was so good at was to imagine his mission in
the future not modernizing

his mission. You know what I mean by that? You can't get to the
future from the present,

so you've got to say what
is this going to be here, and then say, what do I
have to do to make it there?

And then I became the director
of national intelligence. So all those things, like,
none of the jobs I had made

sense until the last one, right? Like, how did she get
all those jobs that were, each one, so different?

But this last one, being
the deputy director of national intelligence? Only a woman who had
done all those things. And so can you describe that,
just for those in the room,

like what is that [INAUDIBLE]? So the principal deputy director
of national intelligence

is a political appointee. [INAUDIBLE] own decision to
become a political appointee,

because forever, then,
you're aligned with whatever administration is in office.

I wasn't worried about
that because everyone knew I was the
intelligence officer,

and so presumed
to be independent, so I thought it was
just a titular thing. The principal deputy
is, as Paul said,

is the senior
intelligence officer. So while Dan Coats, the
director, he was a senator,

he was mostly responsible
for interacting at the policy level. I was the one that ran the
intelligence community.

And the intelligence
community is what? So you did the work? Yeah, 18 agencies, over 100,000
humans, $80 billion during--

when we realized
that we had really missed the digital
revolution because of the war

on terror and we
had to move too. So these 18 agencies, 17
inside the DOD and the CIA.

Is that-- There are only two
independent agencies in the intelligence community. One is the CIA.

Name the other one. Yeah, ODNI. The rest belong to
a secretary, which

is an interesting
leadership position. So every other
leadership position I had was straight line management. I owned the resources.

The principal
deputy, you're really leading, through influence
and budget control,

a loose confederation of
agencies, each of whom is prosecuting
their own program.

You're just trying to
generally align them. And so, you know, now you sit
on some really interesting

both commercial boards but
also advisory boards for the US government, trying to
think about innovation.

What have you learned,
and what lessons do you think we still need
to learn about innovation
in intelligence and defense? So let's talk in two voices.

One, I'll get to you,
because there's some things you need to learn
about innovation

because this is a time that
we just can't draft off the work of our predecessors. So you're going to have
to lead change and lead

the development of things. So I'll get to you. Organizationally, we get
stuck thinking that how
we do things are what we do. Right? What does that mean?

It means that the CIA
was formed in 1947.

Most of the approaches to
intelligence that it has

were based on the world of 1947. Got it. They were built-- our systems
were built when we were hunters

of information and we had
to build special things to go find what
were mostly secrets.

And so there were just-- it was all political military. There were very few
people that we trusted.

We had a singular
adversary, by and large.

And so that was
kind of who we were. When the wall came
down, we pretty much

prosecuted the
world the same way. We just pretended that we
had the same craft applied to everybody else, and we're
dragging the cold war with us

hold the information. It's individuals. And it isn't going
into an office safe.

It's trying to figure
out their communications. So you have the
rise of cyber, you have to be partners with
people you don't trust,

and now there are a whole
bunch of stakeholders at state and local level
because they're the ones that are going to feel the pain.

And then now you go into
great power competition. But almost all the
things we are are

artifacts of how we
began, and layering things on top of those original
processes that we think

are sacrosanct
but, in fact, were just the responses
to certain needs

that were how we should
do it at that time. Give us one.

Secrecy. OK? So if you think CIA, you think
the job of the CIA is secrecy.

Now the job of the CIA
is national security. If I tell you that in 2023,
the National Security decision

makers are disproportionately
in the private sector and in the citizenry, what's
the CIA's responsibility

for national security to those
national security decision makers? How should it think
about open source?

How should it think
about its craft? Classification.

We are secretly collecting
open information all the time.
Think about that. Right? What do you do with that? And we're not dilettantes. That's the systems we have.

So what I would say is you
have to let go of how you do it

from what you're doing. And the easiest way I know
how to get that clarity

is to go back to the
founders' vision. So I will say the
founders vision of the CIA

and intelligence was to
basically know the truth, see beyond the horizon,
and allow leaders

to act before events dictate. Well, there is nothing
passé about that mission.

But how you do it today
is super different. The advent of
commercial technology,

the nature of partners, the
rise of pesky sovereignty in a digitally-connected world.

So many things are
different about that. So you hold on to what
you're trying to do,

and then you think about
how you do it differently. And the other thing I'll
tell you organizationally is everyone hates change.

I encourage you to
hate irrelevance more. Ooh. Good point. Right?

Because that's
what you're doing. You're not changing. You're trying to be
relevant every day. So that's the
organizational one. The individual
one, this is easy.

If you're given a task to
change or it comes upon you, the first thing you
have to do is think.

You have to establish a vision. For god's sake, don't
take somebody else's. And the reason why you can't
take somebody else's is

because along the
path of development, you're going to have
to make some choices. If you've taken
someone else's vision,

you won't know how to make those
choices because you're just carrying them with you. So the first thing
you do is think.

The second thing is you've
got to jump to the future, see what is necessary,
and then build to it.

My best example is JFK
in the space program. We're going to go to the moon
and return men safely to Earth

by the end of the decade. We had no idea how to do it. He envisioned it, we built the
capability, and as a result,

we got Tang and Velcro. There are people today who are
trying to get to the future

by building Tang and Velcro. Sue, these are great lessons. In-Q-Tel, how did
that come about?

How did you apply some of
these lessons to creating that? Great. Undifferentiated task.

George Tenet needed something
cool in his strategic plan. You always think these
things start from really

high-minded reasons. Sometimes you do things
because it's a task.

He turned to the director
of science and technology and said, put something
cool in my strategic plan. She was a woman from Sandia.

She actually had cool ideas
and she was an IT person. She said, I have a vision of an
agile intelligence enterprise.

Go create that. I wanted to say,
what do you mean? Because I didn't get it. She said, maybe an FFRDC--

a Federally-Funded Research
and Development Center. I said, stop talking. I'll go figure it out.

So I thought. And what I thought
was is the nature of public-private
partnership needed to change,

that we had to do
things differently to be attractive to what was
going on in Silicon Valley.

And so, through a
long drawn out process that I won't go through,
came up with the things

that I had to give up
to get to the future. You can't carry
everything with you. You're going to have
to give some things up.

So here are the things
that we gave up. We gave up classified
contracts because I wanted.

We gave up a
statement of work that told a company
what it should do,

and we gave up owning
intellectual property. Those were all really
important things to attract.

But what's the structure
you came up with? Here's what I envisioned.

Had to get it outside
the government. We just weren't trusted
enough, in 1998, by the Valley,

and we're too
hide-bound to change how we did things internally.

So I asked a group
of private citizens to be the founding board
to essentially decide

to come together to form
a company for our purpose. Now because this was
such a radical idea,

I needed a group of
people that I trusted. And so these were the icons
of the defense industrial.

We asked Norm
Augustine-- look him up, Augustine's Law is one
of the best books ever-- was the president of
the board and we put

a bunch of great people on it. And then if the board had to
be appealing to the defense

industrial and the national
security community, the CEO had to be appealing. I know, it all makes
sense now, right?

Yeah, it makes sense. The CEO had to be appealing
to Silicon Valley.

And so we knew that
it needed to be, but I got rid of the
task in seven months.

So over the time I
was tasked to the day In-Q-Tel was incorporated
was seven months. It's super fast, right?

The first board
chose the first CEO, and the first CEO is a guy
named Gilman Louie, who now is kind of iconic.

He's an investor and
he's the cool kid on various senate committees.

Back then, he was
fresh off Hasbro as having developed
Flight Simulator.

And the head of Spectrum
Holobyte, a video game company. That's exactly right. So seven months, crazy idea.

I learned a lot about
the support I needed. You have to
understand your task, so I knew how it
needed to be different.

The one thing I will tell
you, when you innovate, you do have to account
for the reason things were

done as they were in the past. You want to create change
in a big organization,

not just start a new
company to do your thing. You can't just be willy nilly.

So the question was, how am I
going to account for security

differently from how
are you going to? So that's a really great lesson,
is you can't just wish it away.

You have to account
for it differently. And the way I accounted
for it was the capability

was one that we needed to exist. The use of the capability was
what would remain classified.
Very cool. Last question, or-- How did I do? Did I hit most points?

You did. You did. And, of course, I started my
investment career with Gilman, so it's fun to see how
you describe him as well.

Well, he's the best. I mean, we could talk
about why In-Q-Tel has been so successful. It's 25 years old
this coming year.

Part of it was because
we gave up control. Like, if the government
had held on to it,

if the government had
a seat on the board-- George Tenet, the director,
wanted a seat on the board. I said he couldn't have it.

So the success of it has
been that it has been true to the setup, that it was
an independent 501(c)(3) led

we wouldn't have issued the
next contract with them. So we had some control. But you know, Gilman
was really aggressive.

Chris Darby has been
really aggressive. So part of the
success of In-Q-Tel has been that the government
didn't hold too tight,

and so it could become what the
environment needed it to be. And that's super scary, as
an innovator, to let go.

So Sue, maybe kind of
wrapping some of this up, you know, lessons from
Ukraine and lessons

from the intelligence
failure in Israel, how do you think that's going
to affect US, both innovation,

in terms of thinking about
how do we organize forces for drones and the rest,
and then how do we think

about intelligence failures? Either one, or both. Well, lessons from
Ukraine, I think

the biggest one we're
going to take away is you're going to continue
on this path of transparency that you saw it used
by releasing-- there's

been this whole trend
for the past five years of selectively releasing
more classified information

publicly when the public's trust
needed to be in [INAUDIBLE]..

So I think that's one
thing out of Ukraine. The second thing out
of Ukraine is just the value of commercial
capability and the flexibility

that it allows. And so you're going
to, I think, start seeing more commercial companies
engage allies and partners

because they have
some capability to provide intelligence
capability with much less installed base than if
you rely on the US to do it.

There are some
problems with that and that would be a
whole different lecture, so I think there's
some of Ukraine.
Boy, Israel, Hamas--

It's so early, I hesitate
to draw big conclusions, but I'll give you
four that I have. Number one is I fear that
we expected technology

to do everything. That is if we had amassed
all the technology,

that somehow, we would have the
ability to use it as we needed.

This use thing, this
outcome, how is it going to be employed, how is it
getting used, how are decisions

made, I think that
needs to continue to be wrapped around
all the capability

that we're developing. So that's one. Two, I think history will
show that we didn't learn the lessons of 9/11
very well and we weren't

sharing the information we had. I suspect we will find
information that could have been shared and wasn't.

I think there will be some
artifact of decision-making about the risks that allied
intelligence entities wanted

to take in terms of where they
were deploying their forces. And the truth is intelligence is
best gained where the risk is,

but I think that's happened. And I think those are
probably the only three.

The fourth thing I'd say is
much as what happened in Iraq,

we threw a big
rock in a big lake

and we aren't going to know
where those ripples are going to hit, and
it's going to be some time before that happens.

Oh, my fourth rule
would be hubris. I think there was probably
some hubris involved, just thinking that we were
projecting that Hamas

wouldn't do that at the time
or didn't have the capability. And then you just,
in saying that, and I'll turn it back
to Ernestine to close,

is that the CIA was founded as
a human intelligence agency. And I think your
point back to our--

we layered, over the
last 50 years or so, a series of technology
bubbles around that,

sometimes forgetting that
some of the best intelligence is still human. So the best
intelligence is human.

Some of the best decision
making is how humans decide to use technology. Right. There we go.

And Sue, just to
wrap up, what advice do you have for individuals
who are looking to serve?

Best first five years
you'll ever take. There's just-- put
aside the money.

You're going to make
plenty of money. You know, think about it. If you want to think
about it as your gap years

when you would otherwise
be wandering around Europe, which, by the way, I
would encourage everyone to live overseas.

I think that's a super important
thing to get that perspective. The reason I say best
first five years,

maybe I'm projecting
based on my career, I learned about big purpose. Government has big purpose.

There are lots of
things that are being said about
government right now, but I love the
entrepreneurship in America.

I love the vibrancy
of this economy, and it really is a
strength of America.

But there is a big difference
between the weight that's on an entrepreneur that
started their own company and what it's like when
you know that humans are

at stake for what you're doing. So you're going to learn
big purpose and big weight. And the second is
you're going to get

more responsibility earlier. When I left school, my
engineering friends,

they went and they
were on a team that was designing a bushing, and I
was writing for the president.

And that is just the-- feeling weight early is, like,
the best thing you can do.

So best first five years, do it. Plus, you'll get a
security clearance that translates into tens
of thousands of dollars.

And then go do something else. Well, I think this was
an enormously interesting

conversation with an enormously
interesting person that-- Thanks, Steve. I have to tell you,
someday, you're

going to look back
and go, I can't believe who we had speaking-- We're already thinking that.

Yeah. And I'm hoping
some of the things that Sue said not only
resonate in terms of wisdom,

but resonate in the first
five years of your career. I thought of all the takeaways
I'd be thinking hard about,

was that think of this
as an extended gap year, where, in fact, you could
be learning something early

on in your career
that no one else will be able to duplicate in
any other commercial company

in any other place. And you have the rest of
your career to go figure out how to turn that into
enormous amounts of cash

after you leave. And, of course,
we're hoping you're going to stick, but at
least give it a shot.

So with that, thank
you very much, Sue. I thought this was spectacular. And just remember, hopes
and dreams, on you.

Everything we wish for
are on your shoulders.
